newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss report sixteenth mad cow disease case in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Swiss report sixteenth mad cow disease case in 1997.

text.p: Switzerland on Friday reported its sixteenth case of "mad cow disease," or bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), in 1997.
A spokeswoman for the Swiss Federal Veterinary Office (BAVW) confirmed Swiss press reports of the case.
She also said Switzerland was continuing talks with other countries which have banned Swiss cattle and beef imports.

Last year, British scientists said they had identified a new variant of Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD), a brain disease affecting humans, which they said was probably caused by eating infected beef. They are now working to firm up any link.
Up to now, roughly 30 countries have imposed restrictions on Swiss imports of cattle and beef.
The latest case was reported in the canton of Fribourg.
The affected animal was born before the ban on the use of cattle feeds containing meal made from animal remains, which took effect in December 1990.
